This yoga practice is such a world community connector.  I work at a Covid 19 vaccine clinic, and was caring for a woman who had fallen on her way in.  So many people come with great nerves.  Anyway a team of nurses, EMT, and supports were gathered to treat her wounds and provide for her.  We talked about what calms us and the ‚Äúwoman‚Äù said, I have done yoga for over 50 years, 10 minutes every morning.  Then all the rest of us chimed in that we were doing yoga most days during this pandemic.  It turns out we are all doing Yoga with Adriene (except for the person who fell and likely does her own thing well).  It was a great moment of connection.   I have many friends and relatives who are also enjoying Adriene‚Äôs teachings daily.  Thank you Adriene for this gift to me and to so many!

Thank you for your videos. I notice that while your instructions are about breathing in through the nose your exhalation are mostly through the mouth. Is there a specific reason why you may you doing so? A lot of people watch your videos and may get the impression that this is the right way to breathe. Although yogic science particularly emphasises nasal breathing on both inhalations and exhalations. Mouth breathing is reserved for certain specific practices. And even top research papers are proving how imp it is breathe through the nose for balancing the nervous system. But many people who watch your videos may get the impression that is all right to breathe out through the mouth on a regular basis. Just curious so asking!

BRIDGE day 5. Over a month of yoga. I've never done yoga beyond the thirty day January session before (this time BREATH). I've struggled to complete videos for the past week. Just for today, what helped was actively body-scanning before the session, and then doing what Adriene often says: set an intention. My intention was to be present and to be patient. I thought that what that means is actively doing an audible breath and returning to each breath as a beginning, so in other words actively releasing future-tripping, body-shaming and past-judgments, and treating breaths as an arrival. For patience, rather than 'being' patient, I tried to actively release impatience with a mouth exhale. Just for today, that kept me grounded and able to be curious and find play in today's video. As Adriene said about making 'Find what feels good' my own, I'm happy to be finally using as many of the tools that I remembered (from a variety of places) and making them my own collage. My own growth. Just for today. Namaste.

Thank you SO MUCH for sharing this.  I have just written down "Treat each breath as an arrival....release impatience with each exhale....be present and be patient" on one of my beloved sticky notes to come back to as needed (likely, quite often).  How wonderful and helpful.  Take care.

Picking YWA up again, day two. Did 16 minutes flex yesterday. Good. Today felt really good. Have had rotator cuff surgery both shoulders, modified the "side plank" a couple of times so my whole arm was on the floor. Have to sit on a bolster off and on. I'm 4'10'. Longer torso, shorter legs and arms. When one of your legs was up and you were grabbing your toe I compared. My arm is straight up to grab that toe and yours has maybe 20% to 30% bend at elbow. I knew my arms were short proportionally, but this was a 'grab a second look' awakening. I'm all into options and workarounds. I have scoliosis and recurring sciatica (which always works out completely with Yoga sessions). Time passed, but I always keep coming back.  And may I mention that I am 75. The shoulder surgeries dealt a big blow to my practice, along with a few other things here and there. I think you are a terrific teacher. I count on the patter to keep reminding me about self-care. If I couldn't do it anymore, I would tune in just for that infusion of meaning, self-caring and intent. Thanks so much.
That last sleeping Vishnu pose was incredible. Loved the deep stretch through my lower back, side, and hip. Great practice!

200-hour residential new to ashtanga yoga teacher training course in India with Yoga Alliance USA RYT 200 Certification at Yoga School Tattvaa Yogashala, Rishikesh

Tattvaa Yogashala offers the opportunity to journey into the depths of your yoga practice. Located in Rishikesh, the yoga capital of the world, on the banks of the holy Ganges River, our school offers a natural haven for those who seek an experience and environment in which to evolve in body, mind and spirit. We are globally known for world class Yoga Teacher Training in Rishikesh, India. Tattvaa Yogashala is a world renown yoga school specialising in the traditional Ashtanga system of yoga. For years our school has dedicated itself to sharing and spreading the knowledge of this miraculous lineage, continuing to inspire and evolve yoga practitioners around the world.

I've been doing yoga on and on for the last few years, stopping because of the pain it caused in my body ( I have fibromyalgia and arthritis). This time I am going to stick with it, at a slower pace I guess, because I need to be active not get worst. Pain is a vicious cycle.

First of all, I would like to say: Thank you, Adriene! Your guidance is helping me not only with increasing my strength and flexibility but also with reconnecting to myself, to my inner child and reinforcing my self-confidence. I did this video after finishing the very first 30 Days of Yoga challenge you posted almost 5 years ago and I have to say, it had been frustrating for me sometimes, especially with the Half-moon and crow pose. This frustration was coming from my own expectations of myself: I am quite a perfectionist, so when I am not good at something from the get-go, it pains me deeply. The practice helped me to understand that it is not about the results, but the journey which leads us to them. So, today, after being able to direct my own flow on the 30th day of the challenge, I dropped those expectations. I came to this video to flex my hamstrings for my splits practice and, quite unexpectedly, I reached my big toe and straightened my leg in the lying pose. I am not gonna lie, the sensation which filled me was pure amazement. I had to stop the video for a few seconds and just looked at my body in awe. I was able to overcome one of the boundaries I put onto myself, the boundary of expectations which are probably unreachable for me at this point and my body showed me that it is not worthless, it is able to perform some astonishing deeds already. Thank you for allowing me to re-discover myself, Adriene. Namaste.

One of the pieces of positivity that's come out of this whole time for me is getting back into a yoga routine after a couple of years not doing yoga. I've regained so much flexibility! I'm so glad to be back at it

1. scoliosis (since age 12) no real issues except some rhomboid muscle pain that's getting better.

@t joint pain, specifically on the left. Makes it hard to sleep and get out of bed, that's stomach or back sleeping ( back is the worst).
4. Neck pain, mostly from driving but lately from sleeping to accommodate my back.

Hi Rosa! We have a Prenatal Yoga For All Trimesters available in the¬†FWFG Membership - https://yogawithadriene.vhx.tv/¬†as well as in¬†our shop - https://do.yogawithadriene.com/prenatal-yoga
In general, most women are able to continue a regular practice through¬†month eight if they avoid twists below the neck, core activation and anything on the belly. Most will find they will know when something isn't right. Hip openers are good but go easier in third trimester. Modify core breaks with reclined cobbler's pose, modify belly stuff with child's pose or yogi's squat and modify standing twists with wide-legged forward fold.¬†
As always, consult your doctor/physician before starting and follow their advice.¬†

I legit can't put my feelings into words anymore. Each video turns out to be exactly what my mind and body are screaming for time after time, over and over and over again. I've been diagnosed with chronic tightness of all parts of the body as a result of my cerebral palsy but my back and hamstrings are usually the tightest areas I try to stretch out every morning. There's something larger than life in this sense of awareness in this community and that's what makes me love it so much. We all pretty much feel and understand each other without saying a word through our practice together. I am forever grateful to have found this community and to have experienced this sense of awareness with everyone practicing. Thank you, Adriene for the love that never withers. Keep going, everyone.
